chapter.title: System: Util
chapter.para: This chapter introduces the org.opengis.util package from the GeoAPI project and the org.geotools.util package in the Metadata module of Geotools.

The Geotools util package has two roles: first, to implement base elements of the ISO schema and, second, to assemble various utilitarian classes. The standard ISO geospatial specification defines all of its complex computational structures from a set of base elements. Most of these basic elements can be implemented using standard Java language elements, either the primitive data types or the classes in the Java class libraries. However, several of the more complex base elements must be implemented by each geospatial library. These are defined in the GeoAPI interfaces of the org.opengis.util package and implemented in the GeoAPI classes of the org.geotools.util package. The Geotools package also contains a number of utilitarian classes such as derived Collection types and formatting utilities.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The Geotools util package is part of the Geotools Metadata module. Along with the GeoAPI util package, it defines computational structures which complement both the Java language primitives and the Java class library to provide a complete implementation of the base elements in the ISO computational schema. The Geotools package also contains a number of utilitarian classes which are used throughout the library.

note.para: This chapter can readily be skipped and consulted only when an interface or class from this package is required. These elements will be of most use to those delving into the internals of the geographic information system model; general users of the library will not require using the util packages.

sect1.para: Geotools implements a geographic information system based on the standards defined by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in their 191xx series of standards. The base computational structures used by the whole series are defined in the ISO 19103 Standard "Conceptual Schema Language" (see ). Many of these base elements can be implemented by Geotools using primitives and objects defined in the Java Language itself. However, some more advanced structures require their own definition and implementation; those elements are discussed here.

The GeoAPI org.opengis.util package defines several of these base elements through interfaces and classes, including:
The Cloneable interface which marks objects which can be duplicated into new independent structures,
the InternationalString interface can encapsulate a string of characters translated into many languages,
the GenericName, ScopedName, LocalName, and NameFactory interfaces are useful to define a name which contains hierarchical elements separated by a standard separator character,
and the two enumeration classes CodeList and its derivative SimpleEnumerationType.

The Geotools org.geotools.util package serves two separate purposes. On the one hand, the package implements many of the interfaces of the GeoAPI package to obtain all of the base elements of the ISO geospatial schema. On the other hand, this Geotools package defines a number of utilitarian interfaces and classes which are used elsewhere in the Geotools library. These utilitarian classes include:
the ProgressListener interface,
the LiteCoordinateSequence class and its associated factory used to define a compact set of coordinates in the JTS utility library (see ),
the MonolineFormatter,
the NumberRange and associated RangeSet collection,
and a number of collection elements such as the CheckedArrayList and WeakHashMap classes.

note.title: Geotools is not perfectly aligned with GeoAPI
note.para: In general Geotools directly implements the GeoAPI interfaces. For example, org.geotools.util.LocalName is a direct implementation of org.opengis.util.LocalName. However, the libraries evolve according to separate criteria so the relationship between the two projects is not always direct. For example, org.geotools.util.NameFactory does not implement the convenience methods of org.opengis.util.NameFactory and is therefore a completely separate class. However, future work will correct these disparities.

sect1.para: Jointly these two utility packages and the Java language define the complete schema of basic elements which will be used to define the geospatial model implemented in ISO conformant implementations. The rest of the specifications will assemble all their complex structures out of these primitive elements.

sect2.title: Usage
sect2.para: The interfaces and classes which define elements in the ISO geospatial schema are used throughout the Geotools library when those elements are called for in the ISO schema. The classes are used especially in the metadata and referencing modules. The classes which define collection types are used throughout the Geotools library wherever such types can be useful.

warning.title: The Geotools schema may be revised
warning.para: Geotools follows closely the schema defined in the ISO 191xx series of standards. This schema however has never been implemented and a number of questions remain about its completeness and coherency and about the meaning of particular portions of the standard. The Geotools schema may need to change in the future.

sect2.title: Instance Object Model
sect2.para: The Geotools instances of each of the ISO schema elements are relatively simple. The internal structure of most classes should therefore be readily understandable.

sect3.title: InternationalString
sect3.para: InternationalString elements define a computational structures which hold a string of characters along with any number of translations of that string into different languages. The interface can be thought of as a map between a locale key and a string value. The ResourceInternationalString class uses the Java ResourceBundle system to separate out all the different strings stored for translation into language specific files. Those files must therefore be available to the runtime system.

sect3.title: Collections
sect3.para: The *List, *Map, *Set and MapEntry classes follow the usual semantics of Java Collections and should therefore be easily understood.

sect2.title: Code Layout
sect2.para: The structure of the *.util packages in both GeoAPI and Geotools are simply a flat directory with all classes in the top level.

sect1.title: Resources
sect1.para: The ISO 19103 standard defines the schema required by Geotools and therefore the behaviour required of the schema classes defined in these utility packages.

The Cloneable interface is one approach to resolve a design decision made in the early versions of the Java language. See the Object.clone() method javadocs and the documentation for the Cloneable interface. The subject of cloning java objects has garnered a great deal of attention, see, for example, the January 2003 article "Attack of the clones" by Vladimir Roubtsov on JavaWorld.com which posits four approaches to cloning objects: clone methods, copy constructors, copy through serialization and copy through reflection.

The InternationalString structure is relatively straight forward, operating like a key-value map structure. The ResourceInternationalString uses the standard Java resource mechanism documented in the ResourceBundle javadoc pages.

The classes which implement structured collections, such as sets, hashes, and maps, follow the general pattern of such structures in the Java language. The documents for the Java language can therefore help explain the behaviours of these Geotools utility classes.

sect1.title: Practical Information
sect1.para: The interfaces and classes in the util packages follow straightforward java patterns.
The NameFactory class provides static methods for convenience through which to instantiate GenericName instances.

sect1.title: Principal Classes
sect1.para: The GeoAPI and Geotools util packages contain several groups of interfaces and classes each unrelated to the others so each can be discussed separately.

sect2.title: Cloneable
sect2.para: The GeoAPI Cloneable interface differs from the Java interface by defining the clone() method as a public method. An extensive discussion exists on the Java interface and on the decision not to make its clone() method public. Users of the Geotools library should understand the issues involved.

sect2.title: InternationalString
sect2.para: The GeoAPI InternationalString interface is used by the Geotools classes which implement the interface to create a map between various Locale keys and semantically equivalent Strings in the language of each locale. Instance Objects are created or loaded with the needed Locale:String pairs and the translated Strings are returned through a call to .toString(Locale l).
The use of this interface and related classes is illustrated in .

sect2.title: GenericName
sect2.para: The GeoAPI GenericName interface provides a way to store names which are structured into hierarchical namespaces with a constant separation character. For example, each Coordinate Referencing System definition in the database used by Geotools has a label such as EPSG:4326 and this is treated by the referencing module as a GenericName composed of two LocalName instances separated by the colon separator character.
The use of this interface and related classes is illustrated in .

sect2.title: CodeList
sect2.para: The CodeList hierarchy including SimpleEnumerationType allows the definition of an enumerated list of possible alternatives. These two classes use slightly different semantics.

sect2.title: ProgressListener
sect2.para: The Geotools ProgressListener interface can be used to track the evolution of an extended operation.

sect2.title: LiteCoordinateSequence
sect2.para: The LiteCoordinateSequence* provides a way to define JTS CoordinateSequence objects (see ) without the cost of implementing as many objects as does the default implementation.

sect2.title: NumberRange
sect2.para: The NumberRange and RangeSet Geotools classes allow the storing, manipulation, and retrieval of ranges on a number axis.

sect2.title: MonolineFormatter
sect2.para: The MonolineFormatter class facilitates the formatting of user visible output for operations with extensive output such as logging during compilation.

sect2.title: Lists, Sets and Maps
sect2.para: The Geotools util package provides a number of collection implementations which are used in standard fashion.

sect1.title: Tutorial
sect1.para: There is no tutorial for the classes in this package because their use should be understandable to anyone with a basic grasp of the Java language.

sect1.title: Reading More
sect1.para: The Schema classes are used in the metadata and referencing modules of the core Geotools library, especially during the construction of ISO standard data structures. Reading that code should give a sense of how these classes are used in the Geotools library.

sect1.title: Extending
sect1.para: These classes are mostly complete. The schema classes have been defined both in Geotools and in GeoAPI so the feeling of the two projects is that these interfaces are well understood. The collections classes and other useful classes will remain mostly unchanged in this package but more collections may be added as Geotools evolves.
